slides.text:
# 02 "Might makes right" 

 "Might makes right" refers to the idea that power alone is the ultimate determinant of what is morally or ethically "right". 

 Simply because the powerful couldn't be stopped. 

 This power can come in many shapes or forms. In the ancient times it was physical strength, or perhaps tribal lineage. Nowadays we see it in forms of political power, popularity, wealth, qualifications, and hierarchical authority in an organisation. 

 It's a simplistic yet dangerously appealing idea, and most people would agree that the notion of "might makes right" is fundamentally wrong, as it goes against the very principles of civilisation which seeks to rise above the Darwinian laws of the jungle. 

 But, it quickly gets more complicated if you take the logic just *one step further*...

If "Might makes right" is wrong, then logic would dictate that *"Weak makes right"* is also wrong. 

 If we accept the proposition that power alone should not dictate what is morally right, then the logical conclusion is that the weaker party is not morally superior merely because of their lack of power. 

 But in practice, people naturally incline towards supporting the weaker party, or the "underdog". 

 In film, the underdog tale goes as far back as the 1920s, portrayed in classic Chaplin films *The kid* (1921) and *The Gold Rush* (1925), to *Wings* (1927), the first film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. 

 In recent times, the most popular films stretching from the original Star Wars to Harry Potter, Dodgeball, the Matrix, and in TV – Breaking Bad (chemistry teacher with terminal cancer),  Queen’s Gambit (orphan girl), and various protagonistic characters in Game of Thrones.

slides.dialogueText:
Hollywood writing coaches often advice budding writers that the protagonist must be an underdog in order to gain the empathy of the audience, or be "likable" as they would say. 

 In perhaps the most influential screenwriting guide published in 2005, *Save the Cat!*, Synder advises that protagonists should be made underdogs, stressing the significance of tapping into the audience’s empathy so they could “root for” the character and follow their journey as if they were their own.
slides.reference: Snyder, B. (2005). *Save the cat! : the last book on screenwriting you'll ever need*. Michael Wiese Productions.

slides.text:
It would seem contradictory that people's natural instincts are to simultaneously reject the notion that “Might makes right” but accept the proposition that "Weak makes right." 

 The result however, is the same. "Weak makes right" is merely another form of "Might makes right" differing only in the definition of or metric applied to the word "Might". 

 In ancient times, barbarians with bulging muscles are perceived as mighty because they're able to effectively use violence to achieve a desired outcome through brute force. 

 In contemporary society, systems might exist to reward those who are perceived to lack power, which in turn makes them mighty. Societies do this for a variety of reasons, including restorative justice and reducing inequality, to name a few. 

 But many would shun at the retort that "might makes right" and "weak makes right" are logically equivalent, and understandably so.  

 What, then, is the moral justification for the intrinsic support that people feel for the weaker party? 

 Is there a rule or law of morality that would allow us to approach a problem like this with *objectivity* and *consistency*?

slides.dialogueText: Or, are we really gonna let these people win...

slides.text:
Fortunately, not all is lost. 

 Someone came up with a solution a long time ago. Right here in this galaxy, I might add. 

 His name, was Jeremy Bentham. 

 The solution, was this...
It is the *greatest happiness* of the *greatest number* that is the measure of right and wrong.
slides.reference: Crimmins, J. E. (2021). *Jeremy Bentham* (E. N. Zalta, Ed.). Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University.

slides.text:
Bentham's solution to the problem was to axiomatically define the measure of right or wrong, or the judge of morality or ethics, in terms of the *greatest good* for the *greatest number* of people. 

 This approach, is known as **Utilitarianism**. 

 Utilitarianism is a form of *Consequentialism*, a moral framework that assesses the rightness or wrongness of an action based solely on its outcomes. 

 For a utilitarian (or a consequentialist), actions are not judged by intentions, principles, or inherent characteristics or anything else, except by the results they produce... 

 ...and by these **results only**.

There are other forms of *consequentialism*, for instance: 

 - **Egoism**: sounds bad enough already, right? Unlike utilitarianism, which seeks the greatest good for the greatest number, it asserts that individuals *should act * (i.e. morally right to act) in ways that maximise their own self-interest. Hence the name, Egoism. 

 - **Altruism**: this one is the opposite of Egoism, asserting that that individuals should only maximise the benefits of others to *the exclusion of the self*. Codified martyrdom, essentially. 

 Essentially, Egoism and Altruism breaks Utilitarianism into two disjoint sets of the beneficiaries for the maximisation of the good: the others, or the self. 

 But you know what, let's just go with Utilitarianism, at least it would seem reasonably fair to maximise the goods of everyone, including ourselves. 

 After all, who can argue with the idea of *the greatest good for the greatest number*?
slides.reference: see entries on *Egoism* and *Altruism* at Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University. https://plato.stanford.edu/

slides.text:
But another question remains. 

 If we were to accept Utilitarianism as the judge of morality, and we try to achieve *the greatest good for the greatest number*, then what is it meant by "good"? 

 How do you define **good**? 

 Bentham’s answer was again straightforward...
slides.reference: Driver, J. (2009, March 27). *The History of Utilitarianism*. Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Stanford University.

slides.text: Nature has placed mankind under the governance of two sovereign masters, *pain* and *pleasure*. It is for them alone to point out what we ought to do, as well as to determine what we shall do.
slides.reference: Bentham, J. (2012). *An Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation*. Courier Corporation. (Original work published 1789)

slides.text:
Bentham's position can thus be summed in one simple line:

Pleasure good, Pain bad.

Utilitarianism would thus dictate that the *moral thing to do* is to try to achieve: - maximum amount of pleasure; - minimum amount of pain; - for as many people as possible. Well then, having said all that, how might Bentham respond to the proposition that "Weak makes Right" is wrong?

slides.text:
Of course, all that pain and pleasure stuff sound very hedonistic. It has made utilitarianism systemic and practical, but it does sound hedonistic, and many felt that they were shallow because of that. 

 Yet again, if not pain and pleasure, what other measures of "good" can we use? 

 This turned out to be a central issue which later Utilitarian philosophers attempted to address. 

 Perhaps the most prominent one, was John Stuart Mill...

It is better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied. 

 And if the fool, or the pig, are of a different opinion, it is because they only know their own side of the question.
slides.reference: Mill, J. S. (1863). *Utilitarianism* (p. 14). Parker, Son, and Bourn. Image from *John Stuart Mill - Econlib*. (2018). Econlib.

slides.text:
In his work *Utilitarianism* (1863), John Stuart Mill introduced the idea of **higher** and **lower pleasures**. According to Mill: 

 - **Higher pleasures** are those associated with intellectual, moral, and emotional growth, such as learning, art, and companionship. 

 - **Lower pleasures** are those relating to bodily function only, such as food, sleep, or physical comfort. 

 Crucially, when there is a conflict between the higher and the lower pleasures, *the higher pleasures should prevail*. 

 It is clearly Mill's position that those who experienced the higher pleasures will know the difference between the two, and the “fool” or “pig” might believe lower pleasures to be sufficient only because they lack the capacity or experience to appreciate higher pleasures.

slides.text:
The strength of the utilitarian argument, combined with its enticing simplicity, has attracted countless philosophers, politicians, and their generals –  the *intellectuals* – over the years. 

 The straightforward principle – *the greatest good for the greatest number* – offers a clear, practical, and *objective* guideline of morality. 

 Throughout history, people have adopted similar thinking almost out of instinct, although perhaps unconsciously and without rigourous rational grounding. 

 Later utilitarians came up with various additions to the theory of utilitarianism, but core tenet remain unchanged. 

 These days, Utilitarianism is in every continent and every industry, simply put, everywhere.

Create all the happiness you are able to create; remove all the misery you are able to remove. Every day will allow you, --will invite you to add something to the pleasure of others, --or to diminish something of their pains.
slides.reference: Bentham’s advice to a young girl in 1830. Bentham, J., ed. by Goldworth, A. (1983). Deontology together with A Table of the Springs of Action and Article on Utilitarianism. Oxford: Clarendon, p.xix.
